video.title: The Best, Worst & Blandest of 2020 (Zero Punctuation)

captions.text: My latest novel, Will Destroy the Galaxy for Cash, has been out on audio book for ages, yes. But, now the
print and ebook versions are available from all good retailers. Courtesy of Dark Horse Books. All the same
words, but now you get to know how all the names are spelled.

It&#39;s the end of 2020, and I think I speak for 
everyone and their clenched sphincters when I say,

thank fuck that&#39;s over with. Let&#39;s hope in 2021 we 
can start rolling things back to the previous more

stable state of hell on earth. We might&#39;ve been 
living in constant fear of climate disaster and

financial ruin under leaders that could barely 
display the minimum pretence of caring, but at

least we could still hug our elderly relatives 
as they died gurgling on their flooded lungs. But

let&#39;s not forget the most important thing: 
making sure that the beings that one day discover

the ruins of our civilization are very clearly 
informed on which video games from this year I

liked and which I didn&#39;t like. And which just sort 
of dropped straight through my perception without

leaving a mark like a high-fibre turd through 
an incontinent rectum. Yes, it&#39;s the 5 best,

the 5 worst, and the 5 blandest, the tiresome 
yearly ordeal that, unlike Thanksgiving, you can&#39;t
use global pandemics to wriggle out of.
[cheering crowd]

This year I coined the term &quot;Jiminy Cockthroat&quot; 
to refer to the gameplay style that every

triple-A game has now, stealth action open 
world with crafting and collectibles and

probably that one mission where they take your 
stuff away and leave it on a table six feet

from your cell in an astonishingly small bag. 
But it&#39;s a style that&#39;s overdone for a reason,

so let&#39;s give one of them a prize. Ghost 
of Tsushima, I can&#39;t pronounce your name

without spitting on the mic but your art 
design&#39;s good so you&#39;re officially the
least shit. Have a stale biscuit.

Fifth blandest is a game that started 
disappointing right out of the gate with

its terrible subtitle and then took us on 
a veritable rollercoaster of disinterest.

Amnesia Rebirth. The first Amnesia was a 
game that spawned a genreful of imitators

and all Rebirth seems to want to do 
is sit right in the middle of them
playing with its belly button.
[rain falling]

As any of the agencies currently tracking my 
movements will tell you, I do like weird things.

I&#39;d play a Christmas-themed felching 
simulator that only makes sense to the

homeless meth addict with a shoe on his head 
who designed it, but it has to not run like

gravel through a chocolate fountain. Hence 
Deadly Premonition 2 being 5th Worst. You&#39;re

an odd little duck and I like you, Swery, 
but your amusing quacks can&#39;t keep you out
of the hoisin sauce forever.
[cheering crowd]
When audiences have been awaiting a new instalment of your historically significant shooter

franchise for over a decade, finally releasing a new 
instalment in the middle of a global crisis

exclusive to VR, and as such playable only 
by twelve rich people and their accountant,

requires the sort of psychotic boldness 
that one can&#39;t help but respect. I, for one,

enjoyed Half-Life Alyx, Valve. Perhaps one day 
we&#39;ll all come and join you on your planet.
[static noise]
I was going over some of my previous top 5

videos and thought &quot;Man, do I make a joke 
every single year about the inevitability

of a Ubisoft sandbox being in the bland five?&quot; 
You have to point these things out to me, guys,

most new years I&#39;m too drunk to remember. What? 
Oh, any of them. It hardly matters. Immortals:

Fenyx Rising, there you go. Really shitty title 
and the exploration is about as exciting as
combing nits out of your pubes.
[rain falling]

Fourth worst narrowly missed out on consideration 
for the bland list because, while the game is

undeniably bland, the utter wrongheadedness behind 
its concept deserved extra credit. Minecraft

Dungeons. It&#39;s Minecraft but with no mining and 
no crafting. Were there no six year olds around

who could have explained the problem to you, 
Microsoft? Were they all too busy consulting for
the Xbox marketing department?
[cheering crowd]

Things weren&#39;t looking too great for the Yakuza 
franchise with the last couple of sputtering

instalments, but Yakuza: Like A Dragon turned it 
around with its fun characters and greater lean

into the inherent silliness of the franchise. 
Yakuza has been running out of steam ever since

the zombie spinoff, but I should&#39;ve known the 
series couldn&#39;t even decline unless it&#39;s in an
unnecessarily drawn-out and grandiose manner.
[static noise]
Oh, yes always the best part of this process - having to write  something funny about the year&#39;s third most

mediocre game. Which was Serious Sam 4. Once all 
the unnecessary story and skill tree bullshit

flakes off it&#39;s just another Serious Sam game. 
That&#39;s it. Something that ruled the roost back

when retro-style boomer shooters weren&#39;t common 
but I&#39;m picking retro-style boomer shooters out
of my cornflakes these days.
[rain falling]

God, is there anything worse than a bad game 
that thinks it&#39;s funny? Pustular psoriasis?

Oh. Maybe. The remaining two games on your list? 
ALRIGHT RHETORICAL. It&#39;s Battletoads. Why stop at

boring, poorly designed gameplay when you 
could also add hilarious prolonged comedy

animations to make it slow, clunky and confusing 
as well. It&#39;s like trying to count ceiling tiles
while a clown is sitting on your face.
[cheering crowd]

I just couldn&#39;t decide which of two games 
stood out the most in the ever-overcrowded

field of indie roguelikes. On the one hand, Hades, 
beautifully artistically crafted and all that. But

on the other, BPM: Bullets per Minute, just plain 
more fun. With a primary gameplay loop that makes

me unconsciously dry-hump my box ottoman. So fuck 
it, I&#39;m squeezing them both into the two slot.
Because Indie can also be short for Indecisive.
[static noise]

True greatness has often been found in the 
pursuit of the pointless. Climbing mount

Everest is ultimately pointless, and yet 
every year people kill themselves trying

to do it. You, too, can get in touch with 
that spirit by playing The Dark Pictures:

Little Hope. Because once you 
get through its disjointed,

quick time event riddled story and discover that 
the whole endeavour was completely pointless,
you too will want to kill yourself.
[rain falling]

It&#39;s Remothered: Broken Porcelain, the atrocious 
bugfest that&#39;s unpleasant not in a &quot;creepy horror&quot;

way but more like that weird-smelling kid at 
school who was caught licking the door to the

girl&#39;s toilets. It was probably giving the game 
away to put &quot;broken&quot; right in the title, alongside

a couple of other words placed together with all 
the care and thoughtfulness with which one pitches
soiled underpants into a laundry basket.
[cheering crowd]

Yeah, it&#39;s a bit buggy and has a weak 
ending, but Spiritfarer&#39;s still the

game I think most fondly of from this 
year, the lovely heartwarming cartoon

adventure about how everyone you love 
is going to die. Appropriate for 2020,

really. Your elderly relative might have 
died gurgling on their flooded lungs but hey,

life is a journey and death is coming home. Why 
not imagine them as a giant anthropomorphic toad
and feed them fried chicken on a boat? Okay.
[static noise]

There was a time when Marvel comics getting 
a massive multi-film big-budget crossover

universe would&#39;ve been exciting, 
but now it&#39;s here, and it&#39;s blown

its load a few times over with generic 
supervillains and badly explained Maguffins,

it&#39;s hard to maintain enthusiasm. And the 
fact that Crystal Dynamics managed to take

that and somehow make an even duller and more 
jaded version clearly deserves the top spot

in the blandness list. And perhaps even a 
lifetime achievement award for blandness if
they can be bothered to pick it up.
[rain falling]

I&#39;m not trying to be contrarian, I genuinely 
can&#39;t think of any game that gave me a more

miserable experience than The Last of 
Us 2. And here we fucking go. &quot;Ooh,

look at Mr. Controversial Opinions. You think 
The Game Awards Game Of The Year was actually

the worst game ever, do you? And you think 
all the people who think it&#39;s good are wrong,

do you? And you think The Game Awards 
have their noses shoved so far up triple

A buttholes that they wouldn&#39;t notice a good 
game if it was speedbagging their testicles,

do you? And you&#39;re going to put all these views 
into the mouth of a notional third party in a

weak attempt at creating deniability, are you? 
You gonna interrupt at some point? I wasn&#39;t, no.
